title: The Avenging Conscience: or 'Thou Shalt Not Kill'

sources.title: TheAvengingConscience
sources.description: The Avenging Conscience was directed by D.W. Griffith in 1914. It is 50 minutes long, a step in Griffith's progressive move into feature films. His next film was to me his controversial masterpiece, Birth of a Nation. This film is based on writings of Edgar Allen Poe, it is Victorian and sentimental but it is also quite visual. Rather than be a spoiler I will let the story tell itself. I have added music and sound effects, and I may have gone a bit overboard myself as you will see if you watch it. As for the black rectangle at the bottom of the screen, someone had acquired this definitely public domain film and added their own trademark to the print. I covered this over. I hope that disrespect for a piece of film history does not annoy you as much as it annoyed me.

sources.title: The Avenging Conscience: or 'Thou Shalt Not Kill'
The Avenging Conscience (1914) Crime, Drama, Horror Silent Film
sources.description:
Prevented from dating his sweetheart by his uncle, a young man turns his thoughts to murder.

aka: Thou Shalt Not Kill
Director: D.W. Griffith
Writers: Edgar Allan Poe,  D.W. Griffith
Stars: Henry B. Walthall, Spottiswoode Aitken, Blanche Sweet 
Genre:  Classics, Cult Film, Crime, Drama, Horror, Silent film

metadata.Plot: Thwarted by his despotic uncle from continuing his love affair, a young man turns to thoughts of murder. Experiencing a series of visions, he sees murder as a normal course of events in life and kills his uncle. Tortured by his conscience, his future sanity is uncertain as he is assailed by nightmarish visions of what he has done.
metadata.Actors: Henry B. Walthall, Spottiswoode Aitken, Blanche Sweet
